columns.text: In this exercise, we need to assess the different cases for this project. We will look at the base-case, worst-case, and the best-case scenarios.

**a.** We will consider the given values as the **base-case**. This means that in order to solve for the best- and worst-case values, we need to alter the values by $10\%$. 

For the best-case values, we will increase the quantity and price per unit by $10\%$ while decreasing the variable cost and fixed cost by $10\%$. This means that we will multiply the base value by $1.10$ for the increase and $0.90$ for the decrease. 

The opposite is true for the worst-case values.

Solving for the best-case values or the upper bounds of the variables, we will multiply $1.10$ to the quantity and price per unit to get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Quantity}&=210 \times 1.10\\[15 pt]
&=231\\[15 pt]
\text{Price per unit}&=\$17,500 \times 1.10\\[15 pt]
&=\$19,250\\
\end{aligned}$$

Solving for the best-case values or the upper bounds of the variables, we will multiply $0.90$ to the variable cost and fixed cost to get:


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost per unit}&=\$10,600 \times 0.90\\[15 pt]
&=\$9,540\\[15 pt]
\text{Fixed cost}&=\$560,000 \times 0.90\\[15 pt]
&=\$504,000
\end{aligned}$$

For the worst-case values or the lower bounds, we will multiply $0.90$ to the quantity and price per unit to get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Quantity}&=210 \times 0.90\\[15 pt]
&=189\\[15 pt]
\text{Price per unit}&=\$17,500 \times 0.90\\[15 pt]
&=\$15,750\\
\end{aligned}$$

For the worst-case values or the lower bounds, we will multiply $1.10$ to the variable cost and fixed cost to get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost per unit}&=\$10,600 \times 1.10\\[15 pt]
&=\$11,660\\[15 pt]
\text{Fixed cost}&=\$560,000 \times 1.10\\[15 pt]
&=\$616,000
\end{aligned}$$

OCF, or the operating cashflow, can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{OCF}&=[(\text{P}-\text{v})\times \text{Q}-\text{FC}]\times(1-\text{T})+(\text{T}\times \text{D})
\end{aligned}$$

Where,

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{P}&=\text{Price per unit}\\
\text{v}&=\text{Variable cost per unit}\\
\text{Q}&=\text{Quantity}\\
\text{FC}&=\text{Fixed cost}\\
\text{T}&=\text{Tax rate}\\
\text{D}&=\text{Depreciation}=\dfrac{\text{Initial cost}}{\text{Time}}
\end{aligned}$$

Solving for the cashflow using the base values, will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{OCF}&=[(\$17,500-\$10,600)\times 210-\$560,000]\\
&\times(1-0.21)+(0.21 \times \$487,500)\\[15 pt]
&=\$889,000 \times0.79+\$102,375\\[15 pt]
&=\$804,685.00
\end{aligned}$$

The base-case operating cashflow is $\$804,685.00$.

For the annuity factor, we can simply use an annuity factor table and look for the value that corresponds to a $12\%$ return in $4$ years. This value is given as $3.0373$

Substituting these values for the base-case NPV, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NPV}_{\text{base}}&=-\$1,950,000+\$804,685.00 \times 3.0373\\[15 pt]
&=\$494,069.75
\end{aligned}$$

The base-case NPV is $\$494,069.75$

For the base-case scenario, we can first solve for the OCF:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{OCF}_{\text{best}}&=[(\$19,250-\$9,540)\times 231-\$504,000]\\
&\times(1-0.21)+(0.21 \times \$487,500)\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,739,010 \times0.79+\$102,375\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,476,192.90
\end{aligned}$$

The best-case OCF is $\$1,476,192.90$

Substitute the best-case OCF to the formula for NPV to get the best-case NPV. Take note that we are still using the same annuity factor since the duration and the rate of return did not change.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NPV}_{\text{best}}&=-\$1,950,000+\$1,476,192.90\times 3.0373\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,533,640.70
\end{aligned}$$

The best-case NPV is $\$2,533,640.70$

For the worst-case scenario, we can first solve for the OCF:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{OCF}_{\text{worst}}&=[(\$15,750-\$11,660)\times 189-\$616,000]\\
&\times(1-0.21)+(0.21 \times \$487,500)\\[15 pt]
&=\$157,010\times0.79+\$102,375\\[15 pt]
&=\$226,412.90
\end{aligned}$$

The best-case OCF is $\$1,476,192.90$

Substitute the worst-case OCF to the formula for NPV to get the worst-case NPV. Take note that we are still using the same annuity factor since the duration and the rate of return did not change.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NPV}_{\text{worst}}&=-\$1,950,000+\$226,412.90\times 3.0373\\[15 pt]
&=-\$1,262,316.10
\end{aligned}$$

The worst-case NPV is $\$1,262,316.10$

For this, we can use either of the values (best-case or worst-case). In this solution, we will use the best-case values. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{\Delta \text{NPV}}{\Delta \text{FC}}&=\dfrac{\text{NPV}_{\text{best}}-\text{NPV}_{\text{base}}}{\text{FC}_{\text{best}}-\text{FC}_{\text{base}}}\\

\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{\Delta \text{NPV}}{\Delta \text{FC}}&=\dfrac{\$2,533,640.70-\$494,069.75}{\$504,000-\$560,000}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{\$2,039,570.95}{-\$56,000}\\[15 pt]
&=-36.42
\end{aligned}$$

This means that every $\$1$ dollar increase in the fixed cost, the NPV decreases by $\$36.42$

Substituting the base values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Q}&=\dfrac{\$560,000}{\$17,500-\$10,600}\\[15 pt]
&=81.16
\end{aligned}$$

The cash break-even point is $81.16$ units.

Substituting the base values, we get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Q}&=\dfrac{\$560,000+\$487,500}{\$17,500-\$10,600}\\[15 pt]
&=151.81
\end{aligned}$$

The accounting break-even is achieved at $151.81$ units

Since at accounting break-even, the revenue is zero, this means that the cashflow and the depreciation are equal. Therefore:

$$\begin{aligned}
DOL&=1+\dfrac{\$560,000}{\$487,500}\\[15 pt]
&=2.15
\end{aligned}$$

The DOL at accounting break-even is $2.15$. This means that every single increase in the number of units sold will result in a $2.15\%$ increase in the operating cashflow.
